newsitem.title: UK: Licht sees slightly higher EU 97/98 sugar beet area.
newsitem.headline: Licht sees slightly higher EU 97/98 sugar beet area.

text.p: The European Union's (EU) beet sowing area should reach 2.05 million hectares in 1997/98, slightly up on the 2.03 million reported for 1996/97, statistician F.O. Licht said on Thursday.
The area in France, the EU's largest sugar producer, was estimated at 420,000 hectares after a previous 425,000, Licht said in its first estimate of European sugar beet areas.

"It was at first expected that the area in France would be higher but the surplus of sugar brought forward from last season combined with lower world market prices appear to have discouraged farmers and sowings are now expected to fall somewhat below last season's area."
Beet sowing areas should remain largely unchanged in Germany and Britain, Licht said. Belgium's area was expected to fall slightly by 3,000 hectares to 101,000.
Italy was expected to see a recovery in its beet area to 275,000 hectares after last year's beet pricing sparked a fall in the sowing area.
"There was a dramatic fall in sowings in Italy last year due to a change in pricing arrangements but a significant recovery can be expected in 1997," it said.
The other two EU members producing in excess of one mn tonnes of sugar -- Spain and the Netherlands -- are both expecting small declines in area.
Licht forecast Spain's beet area at 155,000 hectares, 5,000 lower than in 1996/97, and the Dutch area was estimated at 115,000 hectares after a previous 117,000.
